columns.text: In this exercise, we have to determine the effect of the distribution of the stock dividend on the equity accounts.

**Stock dividend** is a dividend payment to shareholders that is made in shares rather than as cash. It can be classified as small share dividends and large share dividends.

If the shares issued is less than 25% of the total number of shares outstanding, it is considered as **small share dividends**. Whereas, if the shares issued is 25% or more of the total number of shares outstanding, it is considered as **large share dividends**.

Let's identify the given amounts in the problem.

| |Amounts | 
|--|--:| 
| Common Stock ($1 par)|$\text{\$ 245,000}$ | 
| Capital Surplus| $\text{618,000}$ | 
|Retained earnings | ${\text{2,758,300}}$| 
| Total Owner's equity|${\text{ 3,621,300}}$ |
|Stock Market Value|$\text{53}$|

 
The company has declared 15% stock dividend.

To determine the effect of stock dividends on equity accounts, first, we will determine the number of stocks declared by multiplying the shares outstanding by the percentage of stock dividend.

$$ \begin{aligned}
\text{Num. of SD} &= \text{SO}\times{\text{r}}\\[10pt]
&= \text{245,000}\times{\text{15\%}}\\[10pt]
&=\boxed{\text{36,750 shares}}\\
\end{aligned}$$


Where: 

SD - Share Dividends

SO - Shares outstanding

r - Percentage of stock dividend

Next, let's compute the new common stock by multiplying the sum of shares outstanding and num. of stock dividend by the par value.

$$ \begin{aligned}
\text{New Common Stock} &= (\text{SO}+\text{Num. of SD}) \times {\text{Par Value}}\\[10pt]
&= (\text{245,000}+\text{36,750}) \times {\text{\$ 1}}\\[10pt]
&= \text{\$\hspace{5pt}281,750}\times{\text{\$ 1}}\\[10pt]
&=\boxed{\textbf{\$\hspace{5pt}281,750}}\\
\end{aligned}$$


**As a result, the value of common stock increased from $245,000 to $281,750.**

Next, let's compute the effect on the additional capital surplus.  It is computed by multiplying the number of share dividends by the price per share.

$$ \begin{aligned}
\text{Add'l  Capital Surplus} &= \text{Num. of SD}\times{\text{(Share price - Par Value)}}\\[10pt]
&= \text{36,750}\times{\text{(53 - 1)}}\\[10pt]
&= \text{36,750}\times{\text{(52)}}\\[10pt]
&=\boxed{\$\hspace{5pt}1,911,000}\\
\end{aligned}$$

Next, we will add the beginning capital surplus and the additional capital surplus to determine the new capital surplus.

$$\begin {array}{lrr}
\text{Beginning Capital Suplus}&&\$618,000\\
\text{Add: Add't Capital Surplus}&&\underline{1,911,000}\\
\text{New Capital Surplus}&&\underline{\underline{\$\hspace{5pt}\textbf{2,529,000}}}\\
\end{array}$$

**As a result, the value of capital surplus increased from $618,000 to $2,529,000.**

In recording the issuance of a stock dividend, the retained earnings will be debited. Hence, we will compute the effect of the stock dividends on the retained earnings. 

$$\begin {array}{lrr}
\text{Retained Earnings}&&\$ 2,758,300\\

\text{Less: Add'l Capital Stock}&&{\hspace{10pt}36,750}\\
\hspace{24pt}\text{Add'l Capital Surples}&&\underline{1,911,000}\\
\text{New Retained Earnings}&&\underline{\underline{\textbf{\$\hspace{5pt}810,550}}}\\
\end{array}$$

**As a result, the value of retained earnings decreased from $2,758,300 to $810,550.**

To summarize the effect of the stocks on the equity accounts:

| |Amounts | 
|--|--:| 
| Common Stock ($1 par)|$\text{\$ 281,750}$ | 
| Capital Surplus| $\text{2,529,000}$ | 
|Retained earnings | $\underline{\text{810,550}}$| 
| $\hspace{10pt}$Total Owner's equity|$\underline{\underline{\textbf{\$ 3,621,300}}}$ |

**In conclusion, stock dividends have no effect on total stockholders' equity or net assets, but they do have an effect on certain equity accounts. It increases the value of the company's common stock and capital surplus while reducing the value of its retained earnings.**
